Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Strength of Long Ties

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
40 years since the pioneering work of sociologist, Mark Granovetter, on the "strength of weak ties," numerous studies have confirmed his counter-intuitive thesis that individuals are more likely to acquire novel information from an acquaintance who bridges long network distances than from a close friend. Although the importance of bridge ties for diffusion has been well documented, the focus has primarily been on comparing the relational strength of ties embedded in tightly knit circles vs. the relational strength of ties that bridge long network distances, rather than examining tie strengths of bridge ties that span varying network distances.

Drawing on population-scale data from Twitter and other social/communication networks, this project will (a) test the proposition that bridging ties tend to be weaker with the network distance they span, (b) develop an explanation for the relationship between the strength and span-length of bridging ties using statistical and simulation approaches, and (c) further explore the variation in these relationships across countries of different cultures and economic development. This study will contribute to research across the social sciences, including studies of diffusion and contagion, network evolution, social capital, and labor market processes. The development and dissemination of effective methods to collect, analyze, and compare multiple networks constituted by hundreds of millions of individuals will contribute to the social science community that primarily relied on survey-based egocentric network data. The project will also contribute to graduate training on the use of distributed and parallel cloud-computing tools for studying population-scale social networks

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project was to assess and extend a classic sociological hypothesis regarding the strength and "distance" of relationships in social networks. The idea of network distance refers to the potential for a given relational tie to bridge distant regions in a social network and it is measured by the number of intermediary contacts or friends required to reach from one person to another person if the relationship between the two had not existed. The hypothesis, first introduced in the 1970's by Stanford sociologist, Mark Granovetter, states that socially far-apart relationships that are typically relationally weak (e.g. old high school friends who live far apart) can be advantageous for obtaining new information, for combining previously unrelated ideas or information to come up with a good new idea, and for enabling wide participation in social movements.

            A limitation in this line of research, however, has been in the measurement of network distance. While the accurate measurement of network distance requires fine-grained social and/or communication network data at population scale, survey research tools that have been the main instrument for collecting network data during the past 40 years could not be devised to gain information more than a few hundred people in a single study, typically at the scale of small neighborhoods, schools, or companies. As a result of this limitation, researchers could only observe social ties that span relatively short network distances, from which they generally concluded that longer network distance of a social tie tends to be associated with weaker relational strength (e.g. lower frequency of contact and lower affect). This project set out to fill this gap in social networks scholarship by exploring the presence or absence of social ties that span very long network distances, characterize their prevalence, and perform an extended test of the classic hypothesis described above by measuring the relational strength of those long social ties.

            To achieve this goal, the research team first built a distributed data collection tool, which was designed to gather Twitter users' timelines at massive scale. The crawler collected the timelines of 56.7 million Twitter users in eight countries with high Twitter penetration, but varying in national culture and economic development (Japan, France, the Netherlands, Singapore, South Korea, Turkey, United Kingdom, and United States). From the within-country communication networks of Twitter users that were constructed from those users, we found that the network distance of Twitter communication network ties show a highly skewed distribution (Gamma distribution) where the vast majority of ties span short network distances, but a few social ties span very long network distances that are akin to wormholes that create shortcuts in physical space. Surprisingly, we also discovered that these network wormholes are not necessarily relationally weak, as the classic hypothesis would have it, in terms of frequency of contact and of the positive affect words used in their tweets.

These findings contribute to the ongoing debate in the areas of network science and network-based social capital regarding the distinct functional advantages of short vs. long network ties by suggesting that the presence of network wormholes could provide a wide information pipeline through which novel information can travel in large quantities, benefiting individuals who successfully maintain these network wormholes. These discoveries can also contribute to a more elaborate understanding of how various social diffusion processes, from rumors, job information, to political attitudes, could swiftly saturate a population via these network wormholes.
